trans-unit.source: Provides user interface (UI) elements that enable a user to recover or reset a lost password and receive it in e-mail.
In this topic:
[Introduction](#introduction)
[Views](#views)
[Styles and Templates](#styles_and_templates)
[Validation Groupings](#validation_groupings)
[Applying CSS Styles](#applying_styles)
[Accessibility](#accessibility)
[Declarative Syntax](#declarative_syntax)
Introduction
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control assists users who have forgotten their passwords.
It enables a user to request an e-mail message containing either a new password or the password already associated with his or her user name.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> Web control uses Internet e-mail services to send recovered or new passwords to users.
There are inherent security risks with sending passwords in e-mail.
You should determine whether these security risks are acceptable to your site.

If you are not familiar with the set of login controls available in ASP.NET, see [ASP.NET Login Controls Overview](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ac032230-6469-4b03-b68d-03ef2643a24d) before continuing.
For a list of other topics related to login controls and membership, see [Managing Users by Using Membership](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/824c3a24-f0af-427c-a652-0d2d1e9397cd).

Users can recover passwords only when the membership provider defined in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property supports clear text or encrypted passwords.
Because hashed passwords cannot be recovered, users at sites that use hashed passwords can only reset their passwords.
Accepting user input is a potential security threat.
Malicious users can send data that is intended to expose vulnerabilities or run programs that try generated passwords.
To improve security when working with user input, you should use the validation features of your control and secure any data providers that are configured for your control.

For more information, see [Securing Login Controls](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/d85075bc-9c1a-4453-8a0c-539b10853c9c), [Basic Security Practices for Web Applications](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/3eeeee9e-b09f-4c7f-8ce5-d9ca1f9322ad), and [Securing Membership](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/2dab2012-c278-426a-bb0d-93b260c428a7).

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control can be used when a membership user has not been approved (<xref:System.Web.Security.MembershipUser.IsApproved%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is set to `false`), but it cannot be used when a membership user has been locked out (<xref:System.Web.Security.MembershipUser.IsLockedOut%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is set to `true`).
The e-mail message is sent using the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MailDefinition> class.
To be able to send e-mail to users, you must configure a mail server in your application's Web.config file.
You can change the content of the e-mail sent to users by setting a custom message in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MailDefinition%2A> property.
It is not possible to guarantee that a user will receive or view an e-mail message.
To verify that a user has received a notification by e-mail, consider providing a confirmation link in the message, allowing the user to confirm that the notification was received.
Views
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control has three states, or views:
UserName view -- Asks the user for his or her registered user name.
Question view -- Requires the user to provide the answer to a stored question to reset the password.
Success view -- Tells the user whether the password recovery or reset was successful.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control displays the Question view only when the membership provider defined in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property supports password question and answer.

Styles and Templates
You can use an extensive set of style properties to customize the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
Alternatively, you can apply custom templates to the three views if you need complete control over the appearance of the control.

You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.QuestionTemplate%2A>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SuccessTemplate%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.UserNameTemplate%2A> properties to create templates for these views.
If you define a template for a view, the style properties of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> have no effect.
The following table lists the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control style properties and explains which UI element each style property affects.
For a list of which properties each style applies to, see the documentation for the individual style properties.
Style property
UI element affected
Submit buttons on all views.
Error text displayed to the user.
Links to other pages.
Instructional text on the page that tells users how to use the control.
Labels for all input fields, such as text boxes.
Text entry input fields.
Title text for each view.
Text displayed to the user when the password recovery or reset attempt is successful.
The following table lists which template properties apply to each view in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
For a list of the controls that you must set in each template, see the documentation for the individual template properties.
View
Template property
UserName
Question
Success

When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control is not customized with templates, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.AccessKey%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control applies to the first text box in the control and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.TabIndex%2A> property, which is applied to all text boxes of the control.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control is customized with templates, then the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.AccessKey%2A> property and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.TabIndex%2A> property are ignored.

In this case, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.AccessKey%2A> property and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.TabIndex%2A> property of each template child control directly.

<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control properties represented by text boxes, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Answer%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Question%2A>, are accessible during all phases of the page life cycle.
The control will pick up any changes made by the end user by means of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox.TextChanged> event triggered by the textboxes.
Validation Groupings

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control creates a validation group for all required field validators in the control so that other input controls on the page are not affected by validating the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
By default, the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control is used as the name of the validation group.
For example, a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control with the ID "PasswordRecovery1" will use a validation group name of "PasswordRecovery1".
If you want the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control to participate in another validation group, you must template the control.
Applying CSS Styles
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control lets you specify CSS style rules in markup.
If you use templates to customize the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control, you can specify CSS styles in the markup in the templates.
In that case, no extra outer table is required.
You can prevent the table from being rendered by setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.RenderOuterTable%2A> property to `false`.
Accessibility

For information about how to configure this control so that it generates markup that conforms to accessibility standards, see [Accessibility in Visual Studio and ASP.NET](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/7e3ce9c4-6b7d-4fb1-94b5-72cf2a44fe13) and [ASP.NET Controls and Accessibility](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/847a37e3-ce20-41da-b0d3-7dfb0fdae9a0).
Declarative Syntax
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery"></xref> class.
Use this constructor to create and initialize a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> class.
Gets the answer to the password recovery confirmation question entered by the user.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Answer%2A> property contains the answer to the confirmation question entered by the user.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Answer%2A> property is valid only after the page has been posted back to the server.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
The answer to the password recovery confirmation question entered by the user.
Gets or sets the label text for the password confirmation answer text box.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.AnswerLabelText%2A> property contains the label text for the password recovery confirmation answer text box.

The style settings in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.LabelStyle%2A> property define the appearance of the text specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.AnswerLabelText%2A> property.

If you assign a template in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.QuestionTemplate%2A> property, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.AnswerLabelText%2A> property has no effect.
The default text for the property is localized based on the server's locale setting.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The label for the password confirmation answer text box.
The default is "Answer:"
Occurs when the user enters an incorrect answer to the password recovery confirmation question.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.AnswerLookupError> event is raised when the answer to the password recovery question is not validated by the membership provider defined in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property.
If the membership provider does not support password recovery question and answer, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.AnswerLookupError> event is never raised.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
Gets or sets the error message displayed to the user when the Answer text box is blank.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.AnswerRequiredErrorMessage%2A> contains the error message to display in any <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ValidationSummary> control on the same page as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
The default text for the property is localized based on the server's locale setting.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The error message displayed when the Answer text box is empty.
The default is "Answer."
Gets or sets the amount of padding inside the borders of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery"></xref> control.
The value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.BorderPadding%2A> property is stored in view state.

The amount of space (in pixels) between the contents of a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery"></xref> control and the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery"></xref> control's border.
The default value is 1.
The value of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.BorderPadding"></xref> property is set to less than -1.
Creates the individual controls that make up the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.CreateChildControls%2A> method creates instances of the controls that make up the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control and creates default event handlers for their events.
Gets a reference to a collection of properties that define the appearance of error text in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery"></xref> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.FailureTextStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of error messages in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> class (for example, `FailureTextStyle-ForeColor`).
You can set the property programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `FailureTextStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.FailureTextStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of the following properties:

The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.FailureTextStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.

Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.FailureTextStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> style properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.FailureTextStyle%2A> settings:

When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.FailureTextStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.TableItemStyle"></xref> that contains properties that define the appearance of error text.
Gets or sets the error message to display when there is a problem with the membership provider for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery"></xref> control.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.GeneralFailureText%2A> property is displayed to the user when there is a problem with the membership provider that manages user information for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
Typically, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.GeneralFailureText%2A> property is displayed when the membership provider cannot connect to the data store containing user information.

The text specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.UserNameFailureText%2A> property is displayed in the UserName view when the provider cannot find the specified user name in the database.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.QuestionFailureText%2A> property is displayed in the Question view when the answer entered by the user does not match the stored answer.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.GeneralFailureText%2A> property is displayed for all other errors.

The appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.GeneralFailureText%2A> property is defined by the style settings in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.FailureTextStyle%2A> property.

When you set templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.GeneralFailureText%2A> property is displayed in an optional <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Literal> control with the control ID set to "FailureText".
The default text for the property is localized based on the server's locale setting.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The error message displayed when the user's password will not be sent by e-mail because of a problem with the membership provider.
The default is "Your attempt to retrieve your password has failed.
Please try again."
Gets or sets the URL of an image to display next to the link to the Help page.
The URL of an image to display next to the link to the Help page.
The default value is an empty string ("").
Gets or sets the text of the link to the password recovery Help page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.HelpPageText%2A> property contains the link text for the password recovery Help page.

If a URL is specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.HelpPageText%2A> property, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control displays a link to information about password recovery in the UserName view and the Question view, but not in the Success view.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.HelpPageUrl%2A> property is set to <xref:System.String.Empty>, no link is displayed.
The appearance of the Help page link is defined by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.HyperLinkStyle%2A> property.

When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.HelpPageText%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.HelpPageUrl%2A> properties have no effect.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The text of the link to the password recovery Help page.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets the URL of the password recovery Help page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.HelpPageUrl%2A> property contains the URL of the password recovery Help page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control displays a link to the password recovery Help page in the UserName view and the Question view but not in the Success view.
If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.HelpPageText%2A> property is set to <xref:System.String.Empty>, no link is displayed.

Gets a reference to a collection of properties that define the characteristics of e-mail messages used to send new or recovered passwords to users.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MailDefinition%2A> property returns a reference to a group of properties that you use to define format and content of the password e-mail message sent to users.
Common settings include the subject line and the sender's return address.
For a complete list of properties, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MailDefinition> class.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MailDefinition> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MailDefinition> class (for example, `MailDefinition-Subject`).
You can also set the properties programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `MailDefinition.Subject`).
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
When the e-mail message is created from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MailDefinition> object, it will make the substitutions shown in the following table.
The substitution text is case-insensitive.
Substitution text
Replaced with
The Web site user name of the user.
The recovered password for the user.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MailDefinition.IsBodyHtml%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.MailDefinition> object is `true`, the contents of the mail message will be HTML encoded to guard against cross-site scripting security vulnerabilities for the message recipient.
A reference to a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.MailDefinition"></xref> that contains properties that define the characteristics of e-mail messages used to send users their passwords.
Gets or sets the membership provider used to look up user information.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property identifies the membership provider used to verify user information entered in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
Membership providers are defined in the Web.config file in the <`membership`> section.
Setting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property will change the provider used.
If you do not set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property, it will always return <xref:System.String.Empty>.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.

Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendMailError"></xref> event when an e-mail message cannot be sent to the user.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.OnSendMailError%2A> method is called when the SMTP Mail service throws an exception.

The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendMailError> error and, if the exception is not handled, rethrows the exception while maintaining the call stack.

Examine the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.SendMailErrorEventArgs.Exception%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.SendMailErrorEventArgs> object passed as the `e` parameter to determine the actual cause of the exception.

During development, the most common reason that the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendMailError> event is raised is that the `<smtpMail>` section of the Web.config file is incorrect.
After deployment, this event can occur for a variety of reasons, most having to do with errors in an email address.

You must set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.SendMailErrorEventArgs.Handled%2A> property of the object passed as the `e` parameter to `true` to signal that the exception has been handled; otherwise, the exception is thrown again.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.

Gets the password recovery confirmation question established by the user on the Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Question%2A> property contains the password recovery confirmation question that the user previously established on the Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Question%2A> property is displayed only in the Question view.

If the membership provider specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property does not support password question and answer, the Question view is not displayed and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Question%2A> property is not used.
The membership provider returns the question only after the user enters a valid user name.
Until the user enters a valid user name, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Question%2A> property is <xref:System.String.Empty>.

The style settings in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.TextBoxStyle%2A> property define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Question%2A> property.

When you use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.QuestionTemplate%2A> property to define the appearance of the Question view, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.Question%2A> property is displayed in an optional <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Literal> control with the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property set to "Question".
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/5df3ebbd-d46c-4502-9406-02f9df4ef2c3).
The password recovery confirmation question.
The default value is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
Gets or sets the text to display when the user's answer to the password recovery confirmation question does not match the answer stored in the Web site data store.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.QuestionFailureText%2A> property contains the error message that is displayed when the answer to the password recovery confirmation question does not match the answer stored in the Web site data store.

The style settings in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.FailureTextStyle%2A> property define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.QuestionFailureText%2A> property.

When you use templates to define the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.QuestionFailureText%2A> property is displayed in an optional <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Literal> control with the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property set to "FailureText".
The default text for the property is localized based on the server's locale setting.
The value of this property, when set, can be saved automatically to a resource file by using a designer tool.
For more information, see <xref:System.ComponentModel.LocalizableAttribute> and [Globalization and Localization](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/8ef3838e-9d05-4236-9dd0-ceecff9df80d).
The text to display when the user's answer to the password recovery confirmation question does not match the answer stored in the Web site data store.
The default value is "Your answer could not be verified.
Please try again."

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.QuestionTemplate%2A> property contains the template that defines the appearance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control in Question view.

ID or Command name
Control type
Required/optional
Any control that implements <xref:System.Web.UI.IEditableTextControl>.
Required
Any control that causes event bubbling.
Optional

The Submit control can be any control that causes event bubbling, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Button>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton>, or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ImageButton>.
The control's command name property must be set to "Submit".
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control throws an <xref:System.Web.HttpException> exception if the Question view does not contain the required controls.

No exception is thrown if you give an optional control ID to a control of the wrong type; however, the control is subsequently ignored by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.

Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the control encloses rendered HTML in a `table` element in order to apply inline styles.

In order to make inline style properties such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.ForeColor%2A> apply to all the HTML that is rendered for the control, ASP.NET encloses the rendered HTML in a `table` element.
If you do not want the outer `table` element to be rendered, set this property to `false`.
In that case, if you try to set inline style properties that apply to the whole control, an exception is thrown.
`true` if the control encloses rendered HTML in a `table` element; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Saves any server control state changes that have occurred since the time the page was posted back to the server.
Returns the server control's current state.
If there is no state associated with the control, this method returns `null`.
Saves any state that was modified after the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style.TrackViewState"></xref> method was invoked.
An object that contains the current view state of the control; otherwise, if there is no view state associated with the control, `null`.
Occurs before the user is sent a password in e-mail.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendingMail> event occurs on the server after the user requests a new or recovered password and submits a correct answer to the password confirmation question (if your membership provider supports password question and answer), but before the password is sent to the user in e-mail.
Use this event to do any special processing required before sending the e-mail message, such as setting <xref:System.Web.Mail.MailMessage> properties.

After the user enters a valid user name and, if relevant, a valid answer, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendingMail> event, and then sends the password information to the user in e-mail.
The e-mail uses the settings defined in the `<smtpMail>` configuration file element.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Consuming Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/01e4f1bc-e55e-413f-98c7-6588493e5f67).
Occurs when the SMTP Mail system throws an error while attempting to send an e-mail message.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendMailError> event is raised when the SMTP mail server throws an exception when trying to send an e-mail message.
The default <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendMailError> event does not handle the SMTP error from the mail system.

The method that handles the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendMailError> event must set the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.SendMailErrorEventArgs.Handled%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.SendMailErrorEventArgs> object to `true` to handle the error and prevent it from being displayed to the user.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Implements the base <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.System#Web#UI#IControlDesignerAccessor#SetDesignModeState(System.Collections.IDictionary)"></xref> method.
The design-time data for the control.
Represents the command to perform when the Submit button is clicked.
This field is a string that represents the command to perform when the Submit button is clicked.
The default is "Submit".
This field is read-only.

If you use a template with the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control, you must use this command name for the action performed to submit the form or the control will not function properly.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SubmitButtonText%2A> property is used as the alternative text for the image in browsers that do not display images.

The URL of the image to use as the Submit button.
The default is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SubmitButtonStyle%2A> property defines the appearance of Submit buttons in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> object it returns.

You can set these properties declaratively in the form `Property-Subproperty`, where `Subproperty` represents a property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> class (for example, `SubmitButtonStyle-ForeColor`).
You can also set the properties programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `SubmitButtonStyle.ForeColor`).
Common settings include custom background color, text color, and font properties.

The style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SubmitButtonStyle%2A> property are merged with the style settings for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.

Any settings made in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SubmitButtonStyle%2A> property override the corresponding settings in properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.
The following <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> properties are overridden by <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SubmitButtonStyle%2A> settings:

When you use templates to define the appearance of the initial or Question view of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SubmitButtonStyle%2A> property has no effect.
A reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style"></xref> that contains properties that define the appearance of the Submit buttons.
Gets or sets the text of the button that submits the form.

This property is read-only; however, you can set the properties of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Style> object it returns.

You can also set the properties programmatically in the form `Property.Subproperty` (for example, `SuccessTextStyle.ForeColor`).

Gets or sets the text that appears in the User Name text box.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.UserName%2A> property is saved in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control's control state to preserve the values between round trips to the server even when view state is turned off for the page.

<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control properties represented by text boxes, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.UserName%2A>, are accessible during all phases of the page life cycle.

The following table lists the required and optional controls used in the UserName view template.
ID or Command name
Control type
Required/optional
Any control that implements <xref:System.Web.UI.IEditableTextControl>.
Optional
Any control that causes event bubbling.
Optional

The Submit control can be any control that causes event bubbling, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.Button>, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LinkButton>, or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.ImageButton>.
The control's `CommandName` property must be set to "Submit".
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control throws an <xref:System.Web.HttpException> exception if the UserName view does not contain the required controls.

No exception is thrown if you give an optional control ID to a control of the wrong type; however, the control is subsequently ignored by the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control.

The default is `null`.
Occurs when the user has submitted an answer to the password recovery confirmation question.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.VerifyingAnswer> event occurs on the server after the user submits the answer to the password confirmation question.
You can use this event to prepare the answer submitted by the user for the membership provider, for example by converting it to all uppercase or lowercase letters.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control first raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.VerifyingAnswer> event, and then uses the membership provider specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property to compare the answer entered by the user with the password stored in the Web site.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Events and Delegates](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/d98fd58b-fa4f-4598-8378-addf4355a115).
Occurs before the user name is validated by the membership provider.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.VerifyingUser> event is raised on the server before the user name is submitted to the membership provider to determine whether the user name is valid.

Use this event to perform any preprocessing needed on the user name, such as converting it to all uppercase or lowercase letters, or verifying that the user name is in a particular format, such as an e-mail address.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control first raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.VerifyingUser> event, and then uses the membership provider specified in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.MembershipProvider%2A> property to determine whether the user name entered is a valid user name for the Web site.

If it is valid, and the membership provider supports password question and answer, the password verification question is returned from the Web site and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery> control displays the Question view.

If the user name is not valid, the text in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.GeneralFailureText%2A> property is displayed in the UserName view so that the user can enter a different user name.

If the membership provider does not support password question and answer, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.PasswordRecovery.SendingMail> event is raised and e-mail is sent to the user with the new or recovered password.
For more information about handling events, see [NIB: Events and Delegates](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/d98fd58b-fa4f-4598-8378-addf4355a115).
